senses.de: A strong want or wish for something.
senses.ex: She had a desire to see the world.

Tips.title: Intensity of Wish
Tips.description: Desire often implies a stronger feeling than a simple wish or want.
Tips.example: Her desire to start her own business was unstoppable.

Tips.title: Emotional Force
Tips.description: Use 'desire' to express deep emotional wishes that drive someone's actions.
Tips.example: He pursued his desire for knowledge throughout his life.

senses.ex: She desires to become a teacher.

Tips.title: Formal Tones
Tips.description: As a verb, 'desire' can sound formal or old-fashioned in everyday speech.
Tips.example: She desires to present her findings to the board.

Tips.title: Forming Polite Requests
Tips.description: Using 'desire' can be a polite way to express what you want, especially in writing.
Tips.example: We desire your presence at the ceremony.

senses.de: A physical or sexual want or feeling.
senses.ex: He felt a strong desire towards her.

Tips.title: Intimate Contexts
Tips.description: This meaning of 'desire' is used for intimate or strong attractions to others.
Tips.example: Their eyes met, filled with mutual desire.

Tips.title: Sensitive Subjects
Tips.description: Exercise caution using 'desire' in this context, as it's very personal.
Tips.example: He whispered his desires in a romantic setting.

senses.de: A person that somebody wants to have sexually.
senses.ex: He has been her desire since high school.

Tips.title: Romantic Interest
Tips.description: This sense of 'desire' often implies a mix of admiration and attraction.
Tips.example: From afar, he admired his heart's desire.

Tips.title: In Context of Fantasy
Tips.description: Use it to discuss someone desired typically in a scenario that's not acted upon.
Tips.example: The movie star was a common desire among fans.

senses.de: To express a wish for something to happen.
senses.ex: The council desires a meeting to discuss the issue.

Tips.title: Official Requests
Tips.description: This usage often appears in formal situations like meetings or official documents.
Tips.example: The shareholders desire an explanation for the budget changes.

Tips.title: Expectations
Tips.description: Conveys an expectation that the action requested should happen.
Tips.example: The director desires prompt action on this matter.

Appetite.wordDefinition:
Appetite refers specifically to a physical or physiological craving for food or drink. It is the body's natural urge to consume nutrients for energy and nourishment.

Appetite is applicable in a physical or biological context, while desire is applicable in a psychological or emotional context.

For example, you might have an appetite for breakfast in the morning, but a desire for a successful career in the future.

Aspiration.wordDefinition:
Aspiration means a strong ambition or goal that one strives to achieve in their future. Whereas desire means a strong feeling of wanting something to fulfill one's current needs or interests.

Aspiration is applicable when someone thinks of their future career or life goals, whereas desire can be applied to a current want or need such as craving for food or seeking attention from someone.

Aspiration is a long-term goal, and desire is a short-term want or need.

Crave.wordDefinition:
The words crave and desire both generally mean to want something, but crave has a stronger and more urgent feeling to it.

For example, you might say "I'm craving pizza" when you really want pizza and can't stop thinking about it, whereas you might say "I desire a new job" when you want a new job but it's not as urgent or strong of a feeling as pizza cravings.

Crave is applicable when you want something intensely and urgently, and desire is applicable when you want something but it's not as urgent or intense of a feeling.

Hunger.wordDefinition:
Hunger is a specific physical sensation that is caused when your body needs food to function. It is a necessity for survival.

Desire refers to a want or wish, while hunger specifically relates to the body's need for sustenance.

Long.wordDefinition:
Long can also mean to want something, but it refers more to a general feeling of longing or a persistent desire.

It is often used when talking about something that a person has been wanting for a long time or something that they feel they are missing in their life.

Overall, both words refer to a strong desire for something, but desire is more specific and long is more general.

Thirst.wordDefinition: Thirst is a physical sensation that one feels when they need water to drink. It is applicable when one needs to quench their thirst by drinking water or another hydrating liquid.

Want.wordDefinition:
Desire and want are both words that express a feeling of wanting something, but they are used in slightly different ways.

It is a deeper or more intense feeling than wanting. For example, you might desire to travel the world or to be with someone you love, even if those things are not currently possible.

Want is a more general term that can refer to any type of desire or need.

It is often used to express a more immediate or practical need or desire, such as wanting to eat when you're hungry or wanting to buy a new video game.

Desire is a stronger feeling of longing for something that may be difficult to obtain, while want is a more general term for any type of desire or need.

Wish.wordDefinition:
Wish typically refers to a more passive or hopeful desire, often accompanied by a feeling of uncertainty about whether it will actually come true.

While you may take steps to make your wishes come true, they are often seen as less urgent or important than desires.

Both words can be used in a variety of contexts, but if you really want to convey a sense of strong, driving desire, you might use desire instead of wish.

If you simply have a preference or a hope for something, you would be more likely to use wish.

Yearn.wordDefinition:
Desire and yearn are similar words that express a strong feeling of wanting something.

Yearn implies a deep and intense longing, often for something unattainable or out of reach. For example, you may yearn to be with someone who is far away, or to achieve a goal that seems impossible.

Desire can be satisfied through various means, whereas yearning is a deeper and more intense feeling that may be difficult to satisfy.

quotes.Text: I made my first film when I was 35, so I firmly believe that you don't have to be one thing in life. If you're doing something, and you have a desire to do something different, give it a try.
quotes.Title: American Director
quotes.Name: Ava DuVernay

quotes.Text: A life is either all spiritual or not spiritual at all. No man can serve two masters. Your life is shaped by the end you live for. You are made in the image of what you desire.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Thomas Merton

quotes.Text: If you're bored with life - you don't get up every morning with a burning desire to do things - you don't have enough goals.
quotes.Title: American Coach
quotes.Name: Lou Holtz

quotes.Text: If history and science have taught us anything, it is that passion and desire are not the same as truth.
quotes.Title: American Scientist
quotes.Name: E. O. Wilson

quotes.Text: Listening has importance only when one is not projecting one's own desires through which one listens.
quotes.Title: Indian Philosopher
quotes.Name: Jiddu Krishnamurti

quotes.Text: The most basic human desire is to feel like you belong. Fitting in is important.
quotes.Title: English Author
quotes.Name: Simon Sinek

quotes.Text: Everything is perfect in the universe - even your desire to improve it.
quotes.Title: American Psychologist
quotes.Name: Wayne Dyer

quotes.Text: What do you want a meaning for? Life is a desire, not a meaning.
quotes.Title: English Actor
quotes.Name: Charlie Chaplin

quotes.Text: It is wonderful to have someone praise you, to be desired.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Marilyn Monroe

quotes.Text: From the deepest desires often come the deadliest hate.
quotes.Title: Greek Philosopher
quotes.Name: Socrates
